Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT
text: Fowler) (6.02 p.m.}--The bill before the House, the Social Security Amend the ment (Disposal of Assets) Bill 1999, suffers from the difficulty of most social security legislation in that it offers a one size fits all solution to problems which are often of an individual nature. The social security system is large and complex. To administer the system in an efficient manner requires, some might say, the kind of approach contained in this amendment, that is, to set a rule and apply it in every' single case. Any member who has spent time in an electorate office would soon come to realise that the one size fits all approach creates many cases of hardship, whereas a system able to take a case-bycase approach could be more considemte of compassionate grounds that each individual case may present. This, however, would be far more expensive to administer and would require a complex set of review procedures which would ultimately disadvantage many less able pensioners. But this should not exclude the use of the mechanisms to deal with cases of genuine hardship, particularly where they improve the equity of the system. Despite this flaw and the views of some critics, I believe that Australia's social security system is arguably the best in the world and the most appropriate for Australia. The objective of this bill is to deter the practice of some pensioners, in particular those in receipt of a part pension, to retain pension eligibility by making gifts to family members. By reducing their level of assets, a pensioner may avoid losing a pension entitlement or become eligible for an increased entitlement. The extent of this practice in terms of the number of cases has not been documented. However, the government's estimate of savings growing from $2 million in next year's budget to $4 million per annum in 2002 suggests that the practice of retirees using the gifting measures to maintain pension eligibility is expected to grow considerably. The need for these measures may also be linked to the growth in retirees having considerable asset and income resources who may be eligible for part pension. This contrasts with the situation that existed earlier, when far fewer retirees had additional cash assets income. The bill should, therefore, be seen as a measure which attempts to step in before the practice of gifting becomes too widespread, resulting in a blowout in social ty payments. There would because for concern that, once word got around the local bowling club and many thousands of retirees rushed to get in on the practice, there could be a significant blowout. But here lies one of the concerns that Labor has with the bill, that is, we are not informed of the extent of the problem. By any measure, $2 million in next year's budget is a drop in the ocean compared with the overall social security expenditure. Without clear projections of the potential numbers of part pensioners expected to take advantage of gifting, we really cannot assess the need for this measure. To get hold of those projections, the bill should be subjected to much closer scrutiny, closer than is possible within this debate. I might add that the changes made by this govermnent to asset and income levels as part of what has been described as a very generous treatment of entitlements for higher income retirees may have more to do with the need for this legislation than the government is willing to concede. When you have institutions such as Westpac Bank touting schemes which promise part pension entitlements to retirees with combined pension and private incomes of up to $45,000, you can see why the government is anxious to restrict the practice of gifting for fear that it will lead to an extension of pensioner entitlements at the top end of the scale. But again, we do not have the details. We simply do not know which pensioners are taking advantage of those provisions at present. Some form of inquiry is necessary to shed some light on this. With the benefit of that information we would be better able to consider the effectiveness of this bill in addressing the problem. My greatest concern with this bill is that it is nothing more than a means to reduce expenditure. It does so in a manner which ignores the most fundamental relationships in our society-those of families. Members of the government have frequently stated in this or House their belief in the sanctity of family relationships and responsibilities. We saw an example of this government's attitude when it made changes to the youth allowance which securieffectively applied a means test based on family incomes. Families with modest incomes are now in many cases forced by this government to support unemployed adult children. The reasons given for this were that families have a responsibility to provide support. The government has encouraged and, as I have just said, in some cases forced parents to provide assistance to their adult children. In a similar fashion, the government provides care and assistance in programs such as home and community care, only where family members cannot provide that assistance. The government not only preaches the virtues of family responsibility but enforces those responsibilities in its programs of assistance. It is in those programs that the inflexibility of the policy contained in the Social Security Amendment (Disposal of Assets) Bill 1999 can be seen as harsh and unreasonable. Each year in Australia there are thousands of cases where the families of pension recipients fall into circumstances of financial hardship. The example quoted of the pensioner who gifted $50,000 to his daughter who had four children and whose husband had been killed in a car accident, with the money used to pay off mortgage arrears, is but one of many. It is a story repeated many times over, where pensioners must pay a heavy penalty by way of reduced pension should they assist a family member in financial distress. This has particular relevance in the Fowler electorate where, in some cultures, family members have an obligation to assist relatives in distress and will therefore suffer the loss in benefit to fulfil that obligation. This brings me back to the point I made earlier, that a one size fits all social security system lacks the flexibility to meet the full range of human circumstances. In seeking greater equity, flexibility which makes allowance for the obligation of senior family members to assist those in genuine distress must be built into the system. Surely there is greater equity where a pensioner can be given credit for not having gifted money in previous years and then to gift a greater amount than the annual allowed, whether it be $10,000 or the $5,000 proposed in the bill, to assist a family member in genuine need. Where is the equity when a high income, part pensioner can gift $50,000 to family members over five or even 10 years but a pensioner with fewer assets and less income is penalised if they gift $50,000 in one year out of 10 to a family member in severe financial hardship? Surely there is greater equity to allow for situations where a pensioner can assist a family member suffering financial hardship, without the loss of pension entitlement, than allowing high asset pension recipients to reduce their assets and increase their pension entitlement. The bill before the House addresses only the second of these issues, and it does that only by half measure. It does, after all, only reduce the annual amount of gifting from $10,000 to $5,000. I have no doubt that financial planners will recommend to clients that they continue to gift at the new $5,000 limit in order to maintain pension entitlements. The great majority of retireesparticularly in the Fowler electorate-who have a small amount of cash assets, cash that they have set aside for an emergency, will be the ones penalised by this change. Those who have a family member in financial hardship who require more than $5,000 will find themselves in the dilemma of meeting their obligation to assist a family member but suffering a loss in pension entitlement as a result. What is needed is greater flexibility, but that is not allowed for in this bill. The bill deserves closer consideration in a forumwhere the issues, including those I have raised here, may be investigated and reported on; an inquiry where we may gain better evidence of the effect of the proposed changes; an inquiry which could investigate the possibility of making the system more flexible and better able to meet the needs of the many thousands of pensioners faced with the dilemma of having their pension reduced if they meet their obligation to assist a family member in genuine financial hardship. The one size fits all approach to social security measures lacks the understanding and compassion which exceptional circumstances require. The bill should be opposed on these grounds as an inadequate measure to meet the real needs of pensioners. It represents yet another attack by this government on the incomes of pensioners and retirees. The issue must be investigated in greater depth before the parliament can agree to provisions in this bill.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT
text: This is pure, mean-spirited, Liberal-National Party doctrine. I am disgusted to be a member of a parliament which is introducing legislation attacking our older Australians. The government attacks our pensioners with every piece of legislation it introduces. Older Australians have really suffered under this government. This government has a philosophy of attacking those people in greatest need. If you really are in need, there is absolutely no way you can escape this government. There is a lack of caring, feeling and understanding of the issues that are affecting real people in the community, older people who are out there battling to survive every day. Every day I receive phone calls in my office from pensioners within the Shortland electorate complaining about the treatment they have received at the hands of this government. They complain about the difficulties they are having dealing with Centrelink even now, and they are going to be faced with yet another change, yet another attack on their benefits, on their income and on their freedom to make choices, because that is what this is about. At the moment older Australians can give away $10,000 each year. That is now going to be reduced to $5,000, because once it goes over that amount it will affect theiF pensions. I will share with the House a little story. of old age. My own mother is in receipt of a pension. Ten years ago my sister's marriage broke up and she had to move away from Newcastle where she lived. She moved to the north coast. She was not wealthy; she experienced extreme financial har4!ship. She had two young boys that she had to care for. From having a home and a job in the Hunter, she moved up to the north coast, had no job and no home, and she had to re-establish herself. At that stage, my mother had a little bit of money invested in the bank. She took that money out and my sister was able to get deposit for a home and establish herself. My mother did not give her very much money because she does not have a lot of money. to She is not a wealthy woman. She is just a pensioner on a full pension. Under the proviOnce sions of this piece of legislation that we are considering today my mother would not have been able to help my sister in the way she did. My sister would have been forced to try to get assistance from a government departproblems ment, maybe the department of housing or such, to be able to establish herself in a area, look after her children and give them a home and shelter. This legislation is going to attack families throughout Australia. It is going to make it harder and harder for families that are struggling to be able to survive. Pensioners that want to care for their family, that have a relative that is in need like my sister was, will not be able to help that sibling, or elderly aunt, or niece or nephew. They will not able to be assisted, because of this legislation making it harder every day for pensioners have choices. I think it was the member for Parramatta saying that we on this side of the House are giving way to popularism, that we are just taking the easy option, because 'After all, if somebody is really poor, then they are going to be okay.' Does this government want to see all pensioners in Australia really poor before they can get assistance? We on this side of the House do not want to see that. We believe that older Australians should be respected. We believe that our older Australians should not have to live in poverty. We do not believe that poverty should be a state The electorate that I represent has quite an elderly population. The Hunter as a whole has 9.5 per cent of the population over 70 years of age. The Shortland electorate has part of Lake Macquarie and goes to the central coast of New South Wales, which also has an older population. Lake Macquarie has over 34.7 per cent of the population over the age of 65. The majority of those people receive a pension and the majority of those have a little bit put away so that they can help their families if a any member of their family is in need. This legislation is also changing the pension year. It is changing it from the pension year the financial year. It will raise $4.4 million. Furthermore, it is going to be retrospective. it is passed, it is going to be backdated to 1 July. This is just not good enough. This government continues to attack all older Australians, all people in need within our country. Not only is the government causing for older Australians with this issue but it is attacking health. Mr Speaker, I seek new leave to continue my speech at a later date. Leave granted; debate adjourned. NA Motion (by Mr Vaile) proposed: That the House do now adjourn. South Sydney Rugby League Team

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Grayndler) (6.21 p.m.)On Friday, 25 June this year I had the pleasbe ure of going to the South Sydney Legends dinner. It was a dinner which brought back to many memories for me. People such as Ron Coote, Bob MCCarthy, Bobby Grant, Garry Stevens and of course the great Eric Simms and the great George Piggins were there. I can well remember in 1971 sitting on the SCG hill. I was there with a couple of my cousins. I was a bit short of course and they put me on their shoulder. It is one of the great memories: the victory 16-10 to Souths over St George in that grand final. There were other legends there-people like Jack Rainer, Bernie Purcell and others. South Sydney has a proud history going back to when it was formed on 17 January 1908. They defeated Norths 11-7 in their first premiership game on 20 April that year and they won the first premiership against Easts 14-12 in 1908. This was the first of 20 premierships. This tradition, history and culture is now under threat from the rationalists of the National Rugby League: all that tradition and all that community. The South Sydney Rugby League team is not just about the 13 players who run around in first grade each weekend. It is the kids running around in Souths juniors; it is the mums out there selling raftle tickets so their kids buy football jumpers and socks and play on the weekend; it is the members of the club who own the club--unlike Super League, where Rupert Murdoch's News Ltd owned 51 per cent of each of the clubs that participated in it-and it is the businesses of the district. It is the sense of being a part of community. That is why this debate about the future of rugby league is so emotional. That is why so many people oppose the Super League concept-because we cannot reduce individuals in our society to consumers who sit in front of pay TV screens. The sense of community and the sense of loss which we debate, such as the increase in youth suicide and the rising problems with young people in our society, will not be helped if those great institutions of our local community are simply thrown away because the bottom line is just the dollar. The debate over the National Rugby League and the future goes to the very heart of the future of our society and that increased alienation which people are experiencing. Whether it be the local rugby league club or other sporting organisations or other community organisations such as the RSL, those institutions provide a real basis and foundation for a sense of community. The current debate, with an absurd proposition that somehow you have to reduce the number of teams in the NRL to 14, is very sad. I am sad that Balmain and Western Suburbs have had to merge under pressure. Leichhardt Oval is in my electorate of Grayndler, and I think that many people who have followed Balmain and Wests all their lives-people like Balmain supporter Laurie Nicholls-oppose that move, and I can understand why. South Sydney have been very principled. From the beginning they have shown a great deal of character, led by George Piggins, in rejecting the rationalist message of those people who wish to control what is the people's game. The people's game and sporting organisations really cannot be reduced to mere matters of finance. Newly established teams, such as the Adelaide Rams, which some said had a great future, and the Western can Reds have all gone. Melbourne Storm are there for the moment but one wonders whether they will survive. One thing that is very clear is that the South Sydney Rugby League team means a great deal to a great many people. If South Sydney are not in the competition next year, I for one will not be interested at all in Rugby League and will pursue my interest in AFL because it is simply the case that this kind of rationalism contributes to a loss of community. (Time expired) Second Sydney Airport: Flight Movements

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Macquarie) (6.26 p.m.}An interesting article appeared in the Financial Review on Tuesday this week. This article sheds further light on the debate about Badgerys Creek airport. It may be that my colleagues are sick of my harping on about Badgerys Creek airport, but this article is worth referring to. I will quote one small piece from this article about a consultancy report prepared for the Sydney Airport Corporation to look at the forecasted pressures on Kingsford Smith airport. It says 'looming air traffic capacity constraints at Kingsford Smith Airport can be solved without developing a second major airport in the Sydney basin'. I repeat-'without developing a second major airport in the Sydney basin'. This report, prepared for the Sydney Airport Corporation and echoed in other reports, makes the point very clearly that there are options that are preferable to rushing in and building a second airport in Western Sydney. These options include, firstly, better management of Kingsford Smith airport itself. Kingsford Smith has 120,000 movements a year of planes less than 50 tonnes. This means that valuable capacity is being taken up by lighter aircraft-30 per cent of the flight movements in and out of Mascot are planes with fewer than 30 passengers. The average number of passengers on a flight in and out of Mascot is 75 compared with average world practice of more than 100 and best practice of more than 200. The point is: Kingsford Smith airport is not being used anywhere near capacity. So the first point is that Kingsford Smith can be used much more efficiently. The second point that the consultancy points out is that better development of Bankstown airport, just a few kilometres away from Kingsford Smith, can help relieve some of the capacity problems. According to this consultancy report, by moving the lighter aircraft out of Kingsford Smith into Bankstown we can make Kingsford Smith airport last another 14 years. It is ludicrous that timeslots are taken up at Kingsford Smith airport by light aircraft that could be working just as easily at Bankstown, just a few kilometres away. The third point that this consultancy report makes is that the possibility of speed rail connections will further push out the constraint capacity of Kingsford Smith airport. The development of speed rail links with Canberra, for instance-which should be up and running by 2004-05-should buy us at least another couple of years at Kingsford Smith. That would probably take 3,000 flight movements out between Canberra and Sydney each year. Once we have developed further speed rail links to Melbourne, then we can further put off the constraint limit of Kingsford Smith airport. According to this consultancy report, without changing the curfew, Kingsford Smith could be made to last another 20, possibly 30 years and, on some estimates, even longer than that. These comments echo those made by Tony Stuart last year. The Business Review Weekly of 16 November last year and the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 November reported Tony Stuart, the CEO of Sydney Airport Corporation, arguing that Kingsford Smith could last another 20 or 30 years. There is no sense at all in pushing ahead with an airport at Badgerys Creek if there are better alternatives. If there were no problems with Badgerys Creek you might consider it, but there are problems. There are significant problems. First of all, there are environmental problems. The EIS and other studies clearly show that there are potentially very grave air pollution problems related to an airport in Western Sydney. The studies clearly show that we will frequently exceed accepted ozone levels, on fine particulate levels and possibly on nitrogen dioxide levels. We will also have report problems with the water catchment area. There will also be infrastructure problems. Seventy-five per cent of the users of flights in and out of Sydney live in the eastern and northern suburbs. To have them travelling an hour and a half across Sydney to an airport 50 kilometres west of the CBD is ludicrous to say the least. It will add significantly to congestion on an already overcrowded rail and road network between the CBD and Western Sydney. The infrastructure is just not there to support an airport in Western Sydney. Thirdly, the cost restraints are enormous. On current costs, it is estimated that it will cost $5 billion-without the blow-out-to build an airport at Badgerys Creek and probably another $3 billion for infrastructure for an airport that will not work. It will not solve Sydney's airport problems; it will only create environmental, social and economic problems. (Time expired) Members of Parliament: Flexible Working Hours

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: As all members of this House would know, irregular and often long hours of work as an MP can make home and family life difficult. While we may grumble from time to time, we are-at least in the eyes of the public-well paid for this disruption to our family lives. We have also, in most cases, undertaken this work in the full knowledge that the hours of work would be irregular and that demands on our time would intrude into our family lives. We should therefore appreciate more than most that stable and family friendly hours of work are highly desirable for many Australian workers. But a growing proportion of the Australian work force is finding that their once stable and family friendly work patterns are being changed. In the name of flexible work times, longer shifts are being worked, often in a manner in which overtime and penalty rates are not applied. The traditional standard hours for full-time employees-nine to five Monday to Friday or variations on those hours-are rapidly becoming a thing of the past. Figures compiled by Sydney University Associate Professor Ron Callus suggest that enterprise bargaining has been behind much of the trend to so-called flexible working hours. Callus notes that nearly 80 per cent of enterprise agreements deal with changing the times people work. While the agreements to allow changing the times of work were expected to give workers greater flexibility, for many workers, particularly those with school-aged children, the flexibility benefits only management in having staff on hand for extended trading hours, with workers facing inconvenience and increased costs as a result. The impact of these changes was illustrated recently with the case ofMs Kym Wood. Ms Wood's employer, Steggles, sought to change her start time from 8 a.m. to 6.30 a.m. With three school-aged children, Ms Woods found it impossible to arrange early morning child care and complained to the Industrial Relations Commission. The Kym Woods case clearly demonstrates the difficulty caused to families when changes to working hours are demanded by employers. What was to have been a flexible arrangement which benefited both employer and employee has in this case, and in so many other cases, resulted in gains to companies at the expense of workers. For workers in outer suburbs, extended hours make car ownership a necessity as public transport simply does not have the same flexibility of hours demanded by management. Child-care services outside regular hours are either unavailable or very expensive. But the changes to working hours have an impact outside of the family. For generations, sporting clubs and social organisations have relied on the assistance of volunteers to coach and manage their activities. Over recent years, I have increasingly heard comments from sporting and social clubs that they are finding it more and more difficult to get parents to participate in coaching and managing teams. Too often, calls for help receive the response, 'I can't get away from work in time.' It is clear that longer and less regular hours of work are preventing many parents from actively participating in junior sports development. The contribution of volunteer coaches and administrators has been the backbone of junior sport in Australia and has been the source of much of our nation's success in the sports arena. Sadly, we may pay a high price in reduced participation in junior sport and ultimately be less successful in our national sporting performance as a result. Of greater concern however is the effect of less voluntary work in this generation. Many people are introduced to voluntary work through participation in sport and social activities and continue to participate in a range of community activities with their greatest contribution coming in the years after retirement from full-time work. With fewer people becoming involved due to work commitments, the future of community volunteer work is not bright. As a nation we need to be concerned at the prospect of fewer volunteer workers in the future and the loss in economic terms of the services they provide. While we measure the economic benefits of extended working hours, we should not overlook the economic costs to the community of the loss of volunteer work now and in the future. Parramatta Electorate: Parra Power Soccer Club

Speaker: Mr ROSS CAMERON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Members on both sides will be familiar with Parramatta's very significant place in Australia's history. Many members will be aware that Parramatta was, for example, the site of the first wheat grown in the colony of New South Wales. Mr Horne-James Ruse.

Speaker: Mr ROSS CAMERON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: That is correct. Members will be aware that Parramatta was the site of Australia's first brewery, which will perhaps have particular significance for the two members at the table. Members may be aware that Parramatta was the seat of government in the colony for most of the 19th century. Members may be aware that the site of Parramatta Town Hall is actually the site of the first true market in the new colony. James Ruse was the first person to take himself and his family off the government store and by the sweat of his own brow-his own initiative-he raised enough income to look after himself and his family. But members may not know that this week marks another special anniversary, and that is that 19 years ago this week-in fact, yesterday-was the first soccer match recorded in Australian history. The local club, the Wanderers, accepted as Australia's first soccer club, played its first match against the Kings School, Parramatta, on 11 August 1880. That is just one more of the many firsts that we find in this great city of Parramatta. It is particularly pertinent that i reflect this anniversary this week, because the Parramatta Leagues Club, probably the most significant civic organisation in the city of Parramatta, has recently bought the franchise for a brand new team in the National Soccer League to be known as Parra Power. Characteristically, Alan Overton and Denis Fitzgerald, who really run the leagues club--some would say with an iron rod, but certainly very effectively-have gone out and gathered together the best talent available in Australian soccer. I want to extend my congratulations to David Mitchell, whom many people regard as Australia's best soccer coach. He still has a chance to be selected as the coach of the Socceroos. The team will be playing at Parramatta stadium and they are conservatively expecting crowds of up to 20,000. One of the interesting things that may not be so well known to members is that in the draw-in area which is covered by the Parrarnatta Leagues Club there are 15,000 juniors playing rugby league. What is more interesting is that, in the same area, there are 37,000 kids playing soccer. Parramatta Leagues Club, with an eye to the future, is looking at how it can engage with this young talent and encourage athletic and sporting excellence in Western Sydney, particularly in my electorate of Parramatta. The club is very pleased to have on its benches the likes of three of the Ollyroos who will be representing Australia at the 2000 Olympics. I want to honour the contribution of Jacob Bums, Michael Santalab and Mile Sterjovski, who are the stars of the team there, but who also share a commitment to the fostering and development of young talent. Some will say, 'What is a leagues club doing in soccer?' People may not be aware that leagues clubs around Sydney, New South Wales and indeed Australia and New Zealand make a much wider contribution to their local community than just rugby league. For example, the Parramatta Leagues Club is the principal sponsor of the Parramatta cricket club. Ironically, it is a major sponsor of the Parramatta rugby union club. It is active in countless community sporting organisations, particularly developing the skills and the athletic potential of young people in Western Sydney. on I want to congratulate the Parramatta Leagues Club on its contribution to our great city and I want to wish Parra Power every success in the national soccer league. I certainly hope that it will take its place at the absolute top of the table as we have seen with the Parramatta Eels in the rugby league competition. I wish both teams every success. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd: Steelworks

Speaker: Mr HORNE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In early 1997 BHP announced that they were going to close their steelworks, as we knew them in Newcastle. The Howard government accepted that. Mind you, BHP had tried this on before. They tried it on with the Hawke government, but the Hawke government would not accept it. As a matter of fact, the Hawke government came up with the steel cities plan that saw major investment in the steel industry and BHP restructure. It certainly continued for another 13 or 14 years beyond the time they told the Hawke government they were going to close. In 1997 it took the Prime Minister about four months to respond to the statement by BHP that they were going to close and fmally come up with the princely sum of $10 million for what he called the Hunter Advantage Fund. The Hunter Advantage Fund was a statement by the federal government to match the $10 million that had already been announced by the state government, and $5 million that was announced by BHP itself. This was precisely allocated to create jobs for 30 September this year, because 30 September this year is the date when the steelworks, as we know them, will shut their gate, close their furnaces and stop making iron in Newcastle. It is something that the people in the Hunter region do not know how to accept; we cannot see past that. It is something that all lifelong residents of the Hunter have always had. The steelworks have always been there. As a kid I went to school and university in Newcastle. I and most of the people I was educated with knew that our careers were going to be either in or about the steel or heavy engineering industry-that is the way it was-but that is not to be. With only six or seven weeks to go before this date, let us have a look at what has happened to the Prime Minister's $10 million. This is a disgrace. It is a statement about the lack of care of this government for the high unemployment in the Hunter region. Unemployment in the Hunter is affecting not only the steel industry but also the mining industry. Lack of competitiveness, the inability of the multinationals to employ miners and sell the coal and make their profit has meant that, in the upper valley, we have lost in excess of 2,000 jobs in the past two years. In the industry we are going to lose something like 3,000 jobs. The amazing thing is that the work force around the Hunter is probably as skilled as any in Australia. It is immoral that that region should be suffering unemployment that is some 50 per cent above the national average. October: If you considered its value to the country and what it has contributed over the past century, the Hunter region should have one of the lowest unemployment rates in Australiabecause of the skills and the industry base there and because of what it generates for this nation. But that is not the way it is. But I go back to the Prime Minister's $10 million. The sum of $1 Y2 million has gone to a heavy vehicle interchange. I have no argument with that. It is something that was needed, something that will attract new industry and something that will create jobs. Almost two years ago $3 million was allocated to Comsteel, our stainless steel manufacturer. Comsteel has been sold. The $3 million is sitting there and has not created a single job. Two million dollars went to Forgacs Shipyard. They were building the frigate modules at the time. Those frigate modules are now being built in New Zealand. Forgacs have not taken up the $2 million and they have not expanded their shipyard. That $2 million has not created a job. Three weeks ago, the Prime Minister came to Newcastle and announced $2Y2 million to Impulse Airlines for a call centre that will create 70 jobs-$2Y2 million for 70 jobs. Not one of those jobs will go to one of the people who will lose their job in our steel industry. The whole of the Hunter Advantage Fund and its management have been a disgrace and bring no credit to the Howard government. Let me say fmally that a prime ministerial task force was made up of industrial leaders, union leaders and the Anglican and Catholic bishops of Newcastle, but not one recommendation of that committee has been accepted by the Prime Minister. (Time expired) Living in Harmony Grants

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Curtin) (6.46 p.m.steel It has been argued quite eloquently that Australia's greatest contribution and achievement since Federation have been our substitution of the original Federation belief of White Australia with a multicultural Australia. As Paul Kelly said in an inaugural Politics and the Media Lecture delivered in Sydney last White Australia was the essence of our nationalism, without which it is conceivable there may not have < been a federation at the time it occurred. The policy was of course abolished by conservative governments in the later 1960s. There had already been a transformation of Australia's society and culture in the post-war immigration program. Within my electorate of Curtin alone we are blessed with significant numbers of people from Greek, Italian, and Chinese backgrounds-and others in perhaps fewer numbers. Knowing first-hand the contribution that these groups make to both the local community and the nation as a whole, I support wholeheartedly the need to stamp out racial prejudice, bigotry and intolerance that might still linger among small sectors of the population. I am proud of the fact that this government has introduced a range of programs designed to tackle issues of racism. Tonight I wish to mention the Living in Harmony community grants program initiative being implemented by the federal government in the Curtin electorate, working in conjunction with a highly regarded, respected and hard working group, the Western Australian Chinese Chamber of Commerce. Throughout my professional career I dealt with the Chinese Chamber of Commerce on many issues and I was impressed always with the dedication and professionalism they showed in representing the interests of the Chinese community in Perth. The concept behind this community grants program involves the input of local groups who have the best local knowledge in identifying relevant issues at the grassroots level. The local groups then propose suitable projects which they think will address their own community needs under the banner of Living in Harmony-projects aimed at improving social cohesion, at tackling racism and at generating better understanding, respect and cooperation among people from different cultural backgrounds. The project of the WA Chinese Chamber of Commerce is called Cultural Differences between the East and the West. This received $50,000 in funding from the federal government. The program is a series of free seminars designed to promote effective intercultural hannony and, importantly, continues the work of the chamber, which is already recognised as having a long record of achievement in the promotion of understanding and cooperation between many different professional communities as well as between people from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds. Essentially, this project is all about education. It will see the imparting of essential information about common human values, Asian cultural values, and the norms and strategies for effective intercultural communication. The aim of the seminars is to create a better understanding of the differences between Eastern and Western cultures-and, in doing so, they will aim to reduce many of the misconceptions that lead to less than hannonious relations. It is through better understanding, through addressing misconceptions and by better education that long-lasting changes in attitude occur. On 26 July I was invited by the Chairman of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce, Mr Simon Lee, to speak at the launch of the project at the headquarters of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce within the electorate of Curtin. The other members of the executive who were present included Roger Kwok, Wilson Wu, Ron Jee, John Chan and Jimmy Yong. One could take as a measure of support for the program the fact that many respected figures in Perth were present, including the Acting Commissioner of the Western Australian Police Force, Bruce Brennan. In the formulation of these seminars the Chinese Chamber of Commerce have involved many other interested local groups. They have been very inclusive in their discussions about their seminars. Hopefully the seminars will lead to a greater understanding of what social inclusion and a hannonious society can mean. We must all work to ensure that the benefits our immigration programs have given to Australia are not lost because of any sense of alienation by any sector of society. As the Chinese Chamber of Commerce has recognised rightly, one of the keys to an understanding of social inclusion and to living in harmony is, quite simply, better education. Australian Constitution: Preamble

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (6.51 p.m.)-We have just seen presented to parliament by our Prime Minister a preamble to the Constitution. It includes a reference honouring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the nation's first people, for their deep kinship to their lands and for their ancient and continuing cultures which enrich the life of our country. That is a reference that I as the government's member on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation find absolutely perfect in summing up what I think about how our preamble to the Constitution should reflect on indigenous people. I have just been having a conversation with Jackie Huggins, another member of our Council .for Aboriginal Reconciliation, who was our wnter working with David Malouf in particular to try and sum up what we could say in a onepage document that represented the declaration of the nation. Jackie also finds this statement superb. When we think of our new Democrat representative, Aden Ridgeway, who was instrumental in putting this particular preamble paragraph together, we have a representation of how indigenous people feel in a large part of the Australian population. I want to commend this particular reference. I think it is very important, and I hope all those people who in the future will be looking at this document will be able to see that it represents exactly where we are at right now in this nation with regard to reconciliation. Mr Reith-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Department, on behalf of a number of Labour Ministers' Council (LMC) governments engaged Australasian Research Strategies on 22 May 1998 to undertake research on attitudes to workplace reform. (a) The project is designed to obtain information on the drivers behind attitudes to workplace reform. (b) The Department received copies of the research report and has provided copies to the governments participating in Phase 2 of the project. (c) The Minister publicly released summary findings of the first and second stages of the research on 17 February 1999. A seminar to release the research results from these stages was held on 3 May 1999, involvin! business, academic and media representatives. The report is available free of charge. (d) The company was selected by participating governments of LMC from a panel of 34 researchers established by the Department on behalf of LMC through open advertisement in late 1997 because: - of the panel members, ARS was the only researcher to provide a fully detailed proposal for values research; and - it is the sole supplier in Australia of a qualitative research methodology, VISTA TM values research methodology. This methodology was chosen because it has been used successfully internationally, including by a number of governments, to improve understanding of the drivers behind public attitudes. 2. (e) Yes. (f) To date of the $260,890 paid for the completed Phases I and II of the project, the cost to the Commonwealth was $185,667.50. (g) The percentage of the cost to the Commonwealth for Phases I and II was 71 per cent with the remaining 29 per cent being contributed by the participating State and Territory Governments. Positive Discrimination Programs (Question No. 734) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small business, upon notice, on 21 June 1999: Further to the answer to question No. 24 (Hansard, 9 February 1999, page 2264) in which he referred to positive discrimination measures within the internal management practices of his Department, for those measures which are available to and impact on the general public (a) what measures has the Department implemented which could be categorised as positive discrimination, that is, providing preference to certain citizens on the basis of their gender, sexuality, age, race, place of birth or some other personal characteristic, and (b) what are the details and funding commitments in each case. Mr Reith-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has implemented a number of measures which could be categorised as positive discrimination, in the sense of active encouragement of desirable policy outcomes. These measures are encompassed in the department's Workplace Diversity Strategy. In very broad terms the strategy seeks to build an inclusive environment in which the diverse skills, cultural and backgrounds of departmental staff are valued. The Strategy also emphasises employment equity, which, among other things, ensures that employment decisions are based on merit. The Strategy has been developed in accordance with Government policy and the requirement of the Public Service Act. A key initiative under the Workplace Diversity Strategy is the development and implementation of an Indigenous Australian Recruitment and Career Development Strategy for the department (the Strategy was launched in June 1999). This strategy aims to increase the number of Indigenous Australian staff in the department through recruitment and retention strategies and to improve the representation of Indigenous Australian staff in professional, technical and management positions. Specific initiatives implemented in accordance with this Strategy include: employing Indigenous Australian cadets whereby the department contributes to the cost of university study and provides vacation work placements for cadets; and offering study programs specifically targeted at Indigenous Australian staff, ie the Aboriginal Undergraduate Study Awards (AUSA) and the Aboriginal Staff Sponsorship Program (ASSP). The department also participates in Australian Public Service (APS) development programs targeted at women. For instance, the department sponsors staff on the Senior Women in Management program (SWIM). SWIM is aimed at women senior officers in the department and offers placements in other agencies and organisations plus course work. In addition, the department will next year encourage staff to participate in Springboard, a development program aimed at women in APS 14 classifications. As mentioned in response to the honourable member's previous question, the other area of positive discrimination occurs in relation to Recruitment Services Australia (RSA). The department has responsibility for RSA which administers the Indigenous Australian test for recruitment to designated positions and the Graduate Administrative Assistant Program for the APS, which has special eligibility criteria for Indigenous Australian applicants. (b) Currently the department sponsors two Indigenous Australian cadets and four AUSA recipients. For the next calendar year the department intends engaging an additional eight cadets and offering one place under the ASSP. The combined total commitment for 1999-2000 is $409,000. Funding for the SWIM program for 1999-2000 (one participant for the remainder of 1999 and two in 2000) is $165,000. Costs associated with participation in the Springboard program will be dependent on number of participants sponsored by the department. Funding for the Indigenous Australian recruitment test is on a fee for service basis. Departments using the services of the RSA are charged a fee of $325 per placed applicant. The department is provided with a loan from the Department of Finance and Administration, which is now approximately $890,000, to administer the centralised recruitment program, which includes the Indigenous Australian recruitment program. able to say what is the exact nature of the covenant placed upon the site of Shepherd's Hill Cottage in Newcastle. (2) Has his attention been drawn to a use or proposed use of the site which may contravene the covenant. Mr Fahey-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The covenants placed upon the Shepherd's Hill Cottage site are as follows: (a) The Transferee shall not demolish, damage, alter or change the essential historic character of the said land and the improvements thereon or permit same and shall maintain the land and the improvements thereon in good order and condition having regard to their essential historic character; (b) The transferee shan not use or permit to be used the land and any improvements thereon for any purposes other than as an historical and recreational site provided however that the cottage on the said land (being the cottage known as "No. 45 The Terrace, Shepherds Hill"), may be occupied Uniform Civilian Posi- Positions tions Contractor Saved Saved SERCO/GM 162 174 1823 2058 Uniformed Civilian 330 347 553 906 145 111 32 117 0 0 152 102 353 145 108 269 150 61 1823 2058 Port Services! Support Craft process is not held. as a home for an artist-in-residence or for any similar purposes not inconsistent with the said historical character; (c) The transferee shall not permit any new buildings or structures to be erected on the said land which adversely affects the historic character of the cottage, battery or King Edward Park; and (d) These covenants shall run with the land. (2) Mr Kerry Hickey, MP, Member for Cessnock, recently wrote to me advising that the Newcastle City Council is preparing to obtain consent from the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation to lease Shepherd's Hill cottage to the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol (RVCP). Mr Hickey suggests that this proposed usage may contravene the covenant. Officers of my Department have confirmed with the Newcastle City Council that the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation has given in principle agreement to such a proposal, primarily to enable the RVCP to set up a marine base and thereby overcome radio coverage problems in the area. The Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) has advised my Department that, on the basis of the available information, the use of the site by the RVCP would not be inconsistent with its historic character. In relation to the fitting out of a room for radio communications and providing bathroom and kitchen facilities. however. the AHC has advised that the extent of such work would need to be assessed against the impact that these proposals would have on the significance of the Shepherd's possible.
